hints_html:
To find T(b3) express b3 as a linear combination of b1 and b2. Then use the linearity of T.

To find the matrix representation of T you need to calculate T(e1) and T(e2), where e1 = [1,0] and e2 = [0,1]. Again, linear combinations and linearity of T will be your friends.
hints_latex:
To find \emph{T(b}\textsubscript{3}\emph{)} express
\emph{b}\textsubscript{3} as a linear combination of
\emph{b}\textsubscript{1} and \emph{b}\textsubscript{2}. Then use the
linearity of \emph{T}.

To find the matrix representation of \emph{T} you need to calculate
\emph{T(e}\textsubscript{1}\emph{)} and
\emph{T(e}\textsubscript{2}\emph{)}, where \emph{e}\textsubscript{1} =
{[}1,0{]} and \emph{e}\textsubscript{2} = {[}0,1{]}. Again, linear
combinations and linearity of \emph{T} will be your friends.
hints_raw:
To find ''T(b''<sub>3</sub>'')'' express ''b''<sub>3</sub> as a linear combination of ''b''<sub>1</sub> and ''b''<sub>2</sub>. Then use the linearity of ''T''.
To find the matrix representation of ''T'' you need to calculate ''T(e''<sub>1</sub>'')'' and ''T(e''<sub>2</sub>'')'', where ''e''<sub>1</sub> = [1,0] and ''e''<sub>2</sub> = [0,1]. Again, linear combinations and linearity of ''T'' will be your friends.
question: 5 (b)
sols_html:
Since

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle b_3 = 7b_2 - 4b_1\end{aligned}\]

we have that

\[\begin{aligned} T(b_3) &= T(7b_2 - 4b_1)\\ &= 7T(b_2) - 4T(b_1) \\ &= 7 \left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 2 \end{array}\right] - 4 \left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 1 \end{array}\right] \\ &= \left[\begin{array}{c} 3 \\ 10 \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]

To find the matrix of T with respect to the standard basis, we need to compute the image of each of these standard vectors.

\[\begin{aligned} T(e_1) &= T\left( \left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 0 \end{array}\right] \right) \\ &= T(b_2) \\ &= \left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 2 \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]

and

\[\begin{aligned} T(e_2) &= T\left( \left[\begin{array}{c} 0 \\ 1 \end{array}\right] \right) \\ &= T(b_2-b_1) \\ &= T(b_2) - T(b_1) \\ &= \left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 2 \end{array}\right] - \left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 1 \end{array}\right] &= \left[\begin{array}{c} 0 \\ 1 \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]

And so the matrix of T in the standard basis is

\[\begin{aligned} \left[\begin{array}{cc} 1 & 0 \\ 2 & 1 \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]

”Note that you can check that your result makes sense by verifying this matrix on the vector b3, indeed we have that”

\[\begin{aligned} \left[\begin{array}{cc} 1 & 0 \\ 2 & 1 \end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{c} 3 \\ 4 \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{c} 3 \\ 10 \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
Since
:<math>\displaystyle
b_3 = 7b_2 - 4b_1
</math>
we have that
:<math>\begin{align}
T(b_3) &= T(7b_2 - 4b_1)\\
&= 7T(b_2) - 4T(b_1) \\
&= 7 \left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 2 \end{array}\right] - 4 \left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 1 \end{array}\right] \\
&= \left[\begin{array}{c} 3 \\ 10 \end{array}\right]
\end{align}</math>

To find the matrix of ''T'' with respect to the standard basis, we need to compute the image of each of these standard vectors.
:<math>\begin{align}
T(e_1) &= T\left( \left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 0 \end{array}\right] \right) \\
&= T(b_2) \\
&= \left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 2 \end{array}\right]
\end{align}</math>
and
:<math>\begin{align}
T(e_2) &= T\left( \left[\begin{array}{c} 0 \\ 1 \end{array}\right] \right) \\
&= T(b_2-b_1) \\
&= T(b_2) - T(b_1) \\
&= \left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 2 \end{array}\right] - \left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 1 \end{array}\right]
&= \left[\begin{array}{c} 0 \\ 1 \end{array}\right]
\end{align}</math>

And so the matrix of ''T'' in the standard basis is
:<math>
\left[\begin{array}{cc}
1 & 0 \\
2 & 1
\end{array}\right]
</math>


''Note that you can check that your result makes sense by verifying this matrix on the vector ''b''<sub>3</sub>, indeed we have that''
:<math>
\left[\begin{array}{cc}
1 & 0 \\
2 & 1
\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{c}
3 \\
4
\end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{c}
3 \\
10
\end{array}\right]
</math>
statement_html:
Let

\[\begin{aligned} b_1 = \left[ \!\!\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ -1 \end{array}\!\!\right] \quad b_2 = \left[ \begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 0 \end{array}\right] \quad b_3 = \left[ \begin{array}{c} 3 \\ 4 \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]

Let T denote a linear transformation of R2 such that

\[\begin{aligned} T(b_1) = \left[ \begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 1 \end{array}\right] \quad T(b_2) = \left[ \begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 2 \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]

Find T(b3) and give the matrix of T with respect to the standard basis of R2
statement_raw:
Let
:<math>
b_1 = \left[ \!\!\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ -1 \end{array}\!\!\right] \quad b_2 = \left[ \begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 0 \end{array}\right] \quad b_3 = \left[ \begin{array}{c} 3 \\ 4 \end{array}\right]
</math>
Let ''T'' denote a linear transformation of '''R'''<sup>2</sup> such that
:<math>
T(b_1) = \left[ \begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 1 \end{array}\right] \quad T(b_2) = \left[ \begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 2 \end{array}\right]
</math>

Find ''T''(''b''<sub>3</sub>) and give the matrix of ''T'' with respect to the standard basis of '''R'''<sup>2</sup>
